title: Williamsburg Rural Water v. Williamsburg County Water
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Williamsburg Rural Water and Sewer Company, Inc., Appellant,
				v.
				Williamsburg County Water and Sewer Authority, A Body Politic,
      County of Williamsburg, A Body Politic, Town of Kingstree, A Body Politic,
      City of Lake City, A Body Politic, Town of Stuckey, A Body Politic and Town
      of Andrews, A Body Politic, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2007-MO-071
Heard September 20, 2007 â€“ Filed December
  17, 2007Â Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Larry G.
  Reddeck, of Nettles, Turbeville & Reddeck, of Lake City, for Appellant.Â 
				
				Mark W.
  Buyck, Jr., Mark W. Buyck, III, both of Wilcox, Buyck & Williams, of
  Florence, W.E. Jenkinson, III, Ernest J. Jarrett, both of Jenkinson, Jarrett
  & Kellahan, of Kingstree, and William A. Bryan, Jr., of Collins & Lacy,
  of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  These are consolidated
  appeals from orders of the circuit court relating to the provision of water and
  sewer services in Williamsburg County. Â Â We affirm in part and remand.
FACTS
The
  Williamsburg Rural Water and Sewer Company (WRWSC) was organized as a
  not-for-profit corporation in late 1994-early 1995 for the purpose of providing
  water and sewer service to unincorporated areas of Williamsburg County.Â Â  At the time of its organization, WRWSC gave the County notice of its intent to serve
  certain areas, as well as proposed service area maps.Â  County did not respond
  to WRWSCâ€™s notice but, instead, enacted an ordinance under which County could
  expand its own water and sewer services into the areas.
In
  1998, WRWSC commenced an action against County, contending it had the exclusive
  right to serve the areas in question; WRWSC also sought an injunction to
  prevent County from extending its lines and providing service in the area.Â  The
  circuit court granted Countyâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding WRWSC did
  not have an exclusive right to serve the area.Â  The Court of Appeals
  affirmed this ruling.Â  Williamsburg Rural Water and Sewer Co., Inc. v.
    Williamsburg County Water and Sewer Authority, 357 S.C. 251, 593 S.E.2d 154
  (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This Court reversed the grant of summary judgment to County.Â  Williamsburg Rural Water and Sewer Co., Inc. v. Williamsburg County Water
    and Sewer Authority, 367 S.C. 566, 627 S.E.2d 690 (2006) (Williamsburg I).Â Â 
  We held the Countyâ€™s failure to respond to WRWSCâ€™s notice of intent to provide
  services within ninety days resulted in WRWSC obtaining an exclusive right to
  serve the area.Â Â  The matter was remanded to the circuit court for further
  proceedings.Â Â Â   
After
  our opinion in Williamsburg I was issued, County filed an action seeking
  to condemn WRWSCâ€™s franchise rights (the Condemnation Action).Â  Thereafter,
  WRWSC filed motions to declare Countyâ€™s franchises void; it also filed motions
  for permanent injunctions and restraining orders, contending, pursuant to Williamsburg
    I, that it had the exclusive right to provide water and sewer service in
  the area (the Exclusive Franchise Area action, or EFA).[1]Â Â   
On
  June 12, 2006, WRWSC filed an action challenging Countyâ€™s right to condemn its
  franchise rights (the Challenge Action).Â  The Challenge Action also sought an
  automatic stay of the condemnation action, and sought compensation for Countyâ€™s
  inverse condemnation of and infringement upon WRWSCâ€™s exclusive service rights.Â 
  WRWSC also sought an order declaring all franchises previously granted by
  County null and void.Â  The Challenge Action lists County, the Town of Kingstree, the City of Lake City, and the Towns of Stuckey and Andrews as defendants.[2]Â   
WRWSC
  then filed a motion for summary judgment in the EFA action, seeking a
  declaration that County was without authority to issue franchises in WRWSCâ€™s
  exclusive area, and an order declaring all franchises issued by County null and
  void.Â  WRWSC also requested orders permanently enjoining County from taking any
  further action to provide water/sewer service, and requiring it to cease and
  desist from continuing to provide water and sewer service in those areas previously
  granted franchises.Â   
In
  an order dated August 18, 2006, the circuit court made the following rulings.Â  In
  the EFA action, the court ruled that because WRWSC had not named all franchise
  holders (the Towns of Stuckey, Andrews and Lake City) it could not rule on the
  validity of their franchises, nor could it declare the franchises null and void.Â 
  As to existing franchises, the circuit court denied WRWSCâ€™s motion for an
  injunction, finding WRWSC had not demonstrated irreparable harm and had an
  adequate remedy in an action for damages.Â  The circuit court did, however,
  enjoin County from any further encroachment into WRWSCâ€™s exclusive service
  area, with the exception of any projects currently underway, or projects for
  which funding had been obtained; the court also declined to order County or its
  franchisees to cease and desist from providing water and sewer services to any
  areas currently being served by County.Â  The circuit court declined to rule on
  WRWSCâ€™s contention that this Courtâ€™s opinion in Williamsburg I should be
  applied retroactively.Â   
In
  the Condemnation Action, the Court denied WRWSCâ€™s request for a stay, finding
  the matter automatically stayed by the provisions of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-470
  (the Challenge Statute).Â Â  Lastly, the circuit dismissed from the Condemnation
  Action those municipalities named by WRWSC which may exercise eminent
  domain rights in the future (Andrews, Stuckey, and Lake City).Â Â   
This
  Court subsequently ordered the circuit court to rule on all remaining
  outstanding motions, and ordered the appeals be transferred to this Court.Â  
 
ISSUES
  ON APPEAL[3]

	1.  Did the circuit court err in refusing to stay the Condemnation and Challenge
  Actions?Â Â  
	2.  Did the circuit court err in dismissing the named municipalities (Town of Kingstree, Stuckey, Andrews, and Lake City) from its complaint?Â 
	
	3.  Did the circuit court err in striking WRWSCâ€™s causes of action for inverse
  condemnation and trespass from the challenge action complaint?Â Â  

1.Â 
  MOTION TO STAY AND PROJECTS UNDERWAY 
Initially,
  in the Challenge Action, WRWSC contends the circuit court erred in refusing to
  stay the Condemnation Action.Â  We disagree.Â  The circuit court properly held
  initiation of the Challenge Action operated as an automatic stay of the
  Condemnation Action.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-470 (all proceedings under the
  Condemnation Notice are automatically stayed until the disposition of the
  action).Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not need to stay the Condemnation
  Action.Â   
WRWSC
  asserts the circuit court erred in refusing to stay the Challenge Action
  pending resolution of the ESA.Â  We disagree.Â  We find the circuit courtâ€™s order
  denying the stay is an interlocutory order, such that it is not immediately
  appealable.Â  Â Â Cf. Carolina Water Svc., Inc. v. Lexington County Joint Municipal Water Services, 373 S.C. 96, 644 S.E.2d 681 (2007); Edwards
    v. Suncom, 369 S.C. 91, 631 S.E.2d 529 (2006).[4]Â   
2.Â 
  DISMISSAL OF MUNICIPALITIES
WRWSC
  contends the Town of Kingstree, Town of Stuckey, Lake City and Town of Andrews are necessary parties to the Challenge Action under Rule 19, SCRCP, such that they
  were improperly dismissed from that action.Â  We disagree.
The
  Challenge Action was brought pursuant to S.C. Code 28-2-470 of the Eminent
  Domain Procedures Act, which states:
An
  action challenging a condemnorâ€™s right to condemn must be commenced in separate
  proceedings filed in the court of common pleas in the county in which the
  property or a portion thereof is located.Â  The action must be commenced within
  thirty days after service of the Condemnation Notice upon the landowner.Â  All
  proceedings under the Condemnation Notice are automatically stayed until the
  disposition of the action, if any, unless the landowner and the condemnor
  consent otherwise.Â  No issues involving the condemnorâ€™s right to condemn may be
  heard in the trial upon the issue of just compensation.Â Â   
WRWSC
  named as defendants Lake City, Kingstree, Stuckey, and Andrews, contending they
  have been issued franchises by County, and that the franchises are illegal and
  invalid.Â  None of these municipalities has instituted condemnation proceedings
  against WRWSC.Â  Accordingly, we agree with the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that
  WRWSC may not name potential condemnors in a Challenge Action brought pursuant to
  the Eminent Domain Procedures Act.Â Â  Section 28-2-470 provides a very narrow
  cause of action for which the named municipalities were not necessary parties
  such that they were properly dismissed.  
3.Â 
  INVERSE CONDEMNATION AND TRESPASS
Finally,
  the circuit court held WRWSCâ€™s claims for trespass and inverse condemnation
  were not proper in the Challenge Action.Â Â  We agree.

	In Williamsburg
  I, we stated, 
	The
  statute does not state that the right to provide water and sewer services in
  the area identified by the not-for-profit company is exclusive.Â  In our view,
  the statuteâ€™s silence is the strongest argument for interpreting Â§ 33-35-90 to
  grant a non-exclusive right.Â  On the other hand, the statute gives the
  governmental body ninety days either to accept the not-for-profitâ€™s offer to
  provide the services, or to decide to offer comparable services itself.Â  The
  purpose of the statute is to expedite the provision of these vital services to
  unserved areas; it encourages a not-for-profit corporation to step into a
  governmental void, but effectively gives the local government veto power,
  permitting it to trump the not-for-profitâ€™s offer by making its own proposal
  within a short time period. . . . The purpose of the statute, to expedite the
  provision of water and sewer services to unserved areas, is frustrated by
  anything less than an exclusive right.Â  Cf. Johnston v. S.C. Depâ€™t of
    Labor, Licensing and Reg., 365 S.C. 293, 617 S.E. 2d 363 (2005) (statutes
  should be interpreted to further, not frustrate, legislatureâ€™s intention).

Similarly,
  Â§ 28-2-470 gives a condemnee thirty days in which to challenge the condemnorâ€™s
  right to challenge.Â Â  Clearly, the purpose of such a requirement is to expedite
  the condemnation procedures of municipalities.Â Â  To permit a condemnee to
  attach multiple claims to a challenge action could cause more extensive
  litigation and serve to delay the challenge itself.Â Â  Accordingly, under the
  reasoning set forth in Williamsburg I, we find Judge Cooperâ€™s properly
  dismissed WRWSCâ€™s claims for inverse condemnation and trespass.  
CONCLUSION
We
  find the trial court properly denied a stay of the Challenge Action and
  properly dismissed the municipalities as unnecessary parties to that action.Â  Further,
  WRWSCâ€™s claims for trespass and inverse condemnation were properly dismissed as
  they were unrelated to the Challenge Action.Â  We remand the Challenge Action to
  the circuit court for further proceedings.Â  Upon conclusion of the Challenge
  Action, if it is determined that County may proceed with the Condemnation
  Action, the circuit court is directed to proceed with that action.Â Â  The
  matters concerning the ESA appeal will be held in abeyance, pending resolution
  of the other actions.
AFFIRMED
  IN PART AND REMANDED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES and Acting Justice E. C. Burnett, III, concur. 


[1]Â 
  The EFA action lists County and the Town of Kingstree as defendants.
[2]Â  County had granted franchise rights to each of
  these municipalities during the interim.
[3]Â Â 
  WRWSC raises numerous issues regarding the ESA Action on appeal.Â Â  We decline,
  at the present time, to address those issues.Â Â  The appeal from the ESA Action
  is held in abeyance pending resolution of the Challenge Action on remand.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
[4]Â 
  To the extent WRWSC asserts the trial court erred in permitting County to
  continue with the Kingstree East and Sandridge Projects, this matter falls
  within the ambit of the ESA action, and is simply irrelevant to disposition of
  the Challenge Action, which is merely a contest of whether County has authority
  to condemn WRWSCâ€™s right to serve the area.Â  The ESA appeal is held in abeyance
  pending resolution of the other matters.Â

				Assistant
